bullets.text: U.S. payrolls revised down by 911,000 through March, signaling softer labor market and complicating Fed policy.
Fed schedules third public outreach on bank regulations; corrects consumer credit data; terminates enforcement with Sumitomo Mitsui’s New York branch.
Supreme Court fast-tracks Trump tariffs case; billions in duties at stake for importers and markets.
Klarna prices IPO at $40, above range, raising $1.37 billion—signaling renewed investor appetite for profitable fintechs.
Oracle shares surge on blowout AI and cloud guidance, marking best day since 1999.
Apple raises iPhone Pro starting price; unveils ultra-thin iPhone Air and AirPods Pro 3 with live translation.
Israel strikes Doha targeting Hamas leaders; U.S. criticizes attack, heightening regional tensions and diplomatic strains with Qatar.
Trump orders crackdown on direct-to-consumer drug ads, potentially pressuring telehealth and pharma marketing models.
China grapples with deflationary pressures; investors await inflation data as multinationals reassess pricing and demand outlook.
Nasdaq to invest $50 million in Gemini crypto exchange, signaling cautious institutional reengagement with digital assets.
Studies find Antarctica’s interior warming faster than models predicted, underscoring underestimated climate risks and sea-level implications.
Immunotherapy trial shows roughly 50% tumor responses, including remissions, in aggressive cancers—promising advance for oncology.
DuckDB Node.js packages compromised with malware, highlighting persistent software supply-chain risks for developers.
Microsoft diversifies AI stack by purchasing Anthropic services; investor reaction lifts AI infrastructure partner Nebius shares.
Supreme Court lets Trump temporarily block foreign aid, reshaping U.S. leverage and geopolitical commitments.
